description.narrative: Technical Assistance to legislative development on laws affecting civil society.
Support to civil society to participate in legislative development
This project aims to address these threats by increasing the resilience of infrastructure to climate change in the northern mountains.

title.narrative: Signed cover page of Project Document
Midterm Review for Promoting Climate Resilient Infrastructure in Northern Mountain Provinces of Vietnam

description.narrative: Support to enhance climate resilience of rural infrastructure interventions in northern provinces of Vietnam
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

To increase the resilience and reduce vulnerability of local, critical economic infrastructure in the northern mountains areas of Vietnam to the adverse impacts of climate change and to create a policy framework conducive to promoting resilient northern mountains zone development.
# of vulnerability maps presented and disseminated to % of Northern Mountain provinces.

comment.narrative: n/a – at project outset there is no vulnerability maps to disseminate

Detailed vulnerability maps for at least two northern mountainous provinces (a map for each province), with evidence that these have been presented and disseminated to at least 50% of Northern Mountain Provinces.

On track. Fifty percent completed. Vulnerability assessment results are nearly completed. The CPMU mobilized a firm and an international climate change expert in Quarter III 2014. An international climate change expert supported a national team to finalize the vulnerability assessment methodology introduced at the inception workshop (November 2013). A number of meetings with different institutions/ individuals were held, including a vulnerability assessment methodology consultation workshop in October 2014 to help finalize the methodology. After data collection and analysis, the consultant has submitted a complete database set and vulnerability assessment report to CPMU. Results were shared with Government stakeholders from 15 Northern mountain provinces and downscaled to two piloting provinces namely Backan and Sonla. This work will be further supported by the development of landslide and flashflood risk maps for the whole region and two provinces and will be completed in 2015. They are expected to provide visual vulnerability results based on different scenarios (AR-5, IPCC). This is a valuable opportunity for GoV to place in the public domain the extent of, and the spatial allocation of the likely public expenditures needed for resilience measures, and considered a key impact, as the baseline does not provide information on spatial variability of risk and vulnerability. As such, decision makers can recognize the vulnerabilities of their own provinces in comparison with other provinces. They may also learn how to cope with climate change from the provinces with same situation but higher coping capacities (less vulnerability). On the other hand and more importantly, they can use these maps as inputs for their rural infrastructure-related decisions, especially medium and long-termed planning. Achievements will be shared with Northern mountain provinces through relevant trainings at the end of 2015.

description.narrative: % of public expenditure directed towards the protection of rural infrastructure following the project guidance on climate resilient infrastructure.

comment.narrative: 0 funds invested
On 05 rural infrastructure projects, at least 5% additional public finance invested in infrastructure resilience, over and above SRID pilot demonstration.

On track. The vulnerability index and the hazard impact assessments will assist in the calculation of climate adaptation costs for rural infrastructure projects. The economic analysis team is working on this matter to introduce the formula and a number of case studies as examples. However, it is difficult to apply this formula under the SRIDP sub-projects because they have finished the sub-project screening, which requires economic analysis to be provided in advance. Hence the independent Midterm review team who were mobilized by UNDP-GEF in April suggest that CPMU, UNDP and MARD should discuss how to utilize this result in future projects. This issue might be brought to a PSC meeting which will be organized in late 2015 as expected. Currently, reviewing of the existing data/ situations/ documents/ etc. has finished and the second phase to deliver recommendations is well underway. The following reports approved/ submitted: (i) policy (04 reports): Overview on existing policy and strategy related to rural infrastructure, Report of International good practices in policy and practice for climate resilient rural infrastructure, A thematic report on strengthening the resilience of rural infrastructure to climate change at international level, with focus on: (- Rural road infrastructure;- Rural water supply and irrigation; and, - River protection embankment); Thematic report on development of SEDP and agricultural and transportation sector plans in relation to rural infrastructure of the Northern mountain region; and (ii) economic analysis (02) cost-benefit analysis for climate proofing rural infrastructure projects, Report on Measures to quantify economic damages caused by CC on rural infrastructure in Northern mountain area; (iii) rural infrastructure engineering (5): The report on good international practice of engineering resilience in the context of rural roads, irrigation network and river embankments; Root cause analysis for losses and damages to the rural road infrastructure; Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the irrigation and river embankment infrastructure; The report on rural infrastructure vulnerability assessment to climate change for the Northern mountain provinces in Vietnam; Recommendations on integration of climate change adaptation into rural road investments; and Recommendations on integration of climate change into irrigation and embankment investments; (iv) vulnerability assessment report; (v) capacity strengthening: Report on climate change impacts on poverty reduction and socio-economic development in the northern mountain provinces; Report on the need of capacity strengthening on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces and Report on the capacity strengthening plan on CC adaptation of northern mountain provinces. A series of technical and progress meetings/ consultations/ field trips were held to improve the quality of the outputs and fasten the project progress with participation of various partners at different levels (community, district, province and central levels). Consulted institutions include (i) MARD - Directorate of Water Resources, Department of Construction Management, Department of Planning, Department of Science, Technology and Environment, Institute of Policy and Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development, Institute of Water Resources Planning; Disaster Management Center; New Rural Area Program Committee, Department of Dyke and Flood Protection, Vietnam Academy of Water Resources; National Institute of Agriculture Planning and Projection, Water Resources University, Institute of Water Resources Planning; (ii) MONRE - Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Climate change; Vietnam Institute of Geosciences and Mineral Resources, Institute of Geology; and Vietnam Department of Survey and Mapping; (iii) MOT - University of Transport; Transport Development and Strategy Institute; (iv) 15 project provinces and communes.

description.narrative: Climate Change Adaptation integrated into rural infrastructure (i.e. transport, irrigation, construction and water supply) strategies, policies, plans and regulations.
# of Technical papers providing guidance on mainstreaming climate change into sectorial planning related to rural infrastructure in northern areas.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been a guidance paper at project outset.
A Technical Guidance Paper on mainstreaming climate change into provincial rural infrastructure planning prepared by the project and circulated by MARD.

On track. The project successfully completed a comprehensive review of relevant policies that included a series of stakeholder consultations. Key findings include that most of MARD policies/ strategies do not take climate change into consideration and are not detailed enough for application. The need to employ pro-poor and no-regret approaches for resilience building were also clearly highlighted. The New Rural Development Program, Sustainable Poverty Reduction Program and provincial socio-economic development planning processes were particularly identified as priorities for further analysis and engagement by the project.
A policy consultation workshop at Thai Nguyen province on 9 September 2014 was able to solicit inputs from 11 departments/ institutes from MARD and MONRE and 14 DARDs. The meeting further highlighted the continued interest in learning from international experience in bio-engineering/ low-cost measures to support resilience. A comprehensive review of current rural infrastructure planning, implementation and maintenance and field missions to discuss with key focal points, Government officials and community representatives highlighted a number of issues regarding low-cost measures including bio-engineering measures. The assessment included review of experience from 27 countries from the Netherlands to Laos with legal frameworks, codes and policies and implementation methods for introducing low-cost and bio-engineering options. Analysis of the most recent climate change projections for Viet Nam and their potential impacts in the focus regions was also a key element of this work. With regards to the analysis of key hazards for the region, potential increases in intense and concentrated rainfall, and associated landslide risk, were highlighted as an issue in climate change projections that was particularly of concern with regards to rural infrastructure. Other factors impacting current resilience of infrastructure included poor designs, using unqualified materials, applying unsuitable technical solutions during construction process and O&M. The review also recognized the clear need to integrate climate change into existing relevant codes and standards, especially C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures which has been issued since 1970s. This implies that the vulnerability mapping under the project should take into account of above-mentioned climate disasters. Key steps were also taken into initiating a review of current economic analysis practices and in starting to look at the economic consequences of climate change (losses). This work is likely to bolster the success of the project in suggesting appropriate methods, tools and procedures for climate proofing investment decision-making in the NMP. At a higher (Provincial) level, it is likely that a key tool for climate change adaptation investment guidance will continue to be the application of the MCA Multi Criteria Analysis method, as illustrated by the application of UNDP Teams integrated VA and Hazard models (which adopt an integrated format, in common with ICEM CAM methodology). As an example, work on the VA component has identified marked differences in Vulnerability between NMP provinces and ongoing work on Flood and Landslide Hazard risk is expected to further identify differences between provinces, which can assist to pinpoint the urgency and extent of CCA interventions (investments). (To continue in General Comment box on Basic Data tab)

description.narrative: # of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

comment.narrative: n/a - at the project outset, there has not been a manual to guide mainstreaming of CC into the design of rural infrastructure projects.

02 manuals on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects (01 for rural roads and irrigation, and 01 for embankment) prepared by the project (taking into consideration of results of the demonstration projects) and circulated by MARD.

On track. The review phase indicates that although MARD has launched a lot of rural infrastructure projects, applied technical codes/ standards regarding rural roads come from MOT. However, Ministry of Transport has not really touched climate change adaptation in their projects/ planning/ codes/ standards. Hence, there is a need to improve existing code/ standards to consider climate resilience for these infrastructures. The review phase also revealed that it is not at all simple to insert project recommendations into existing codes/ standards of MOT since it is not only a long process but also requires inter-ministerial discussions. Despite such difficulties, some findings and recommendations mentioned in the report "Root cause analysis for loses and damages to the rural road infrastructure" have contributed to the draft manual of rural transport roads of the MOT. The contents inserted into the draft consist of (i) climate change impacts on rural roads; (ii) the importance of construction of drain structures; (iii) a number of feasible technical measures that can be applied; (iv) a number of pavements that can increase the resilience to climate change and (v) the importance of bio-engineering measures for slope protection. This can be seen as a great effort of the project already. Besides, the project has had similar contribution to the upgrading of two technical standards of MARD namely slope concrete standard and dam safety standard. The meetings with the two standard improvement teams have shown their high consensus in increasing the thickness of slope slabs to decrease the oxidation as consequence of extreme weather. Project recommendations have been appreciated and captured in the reports of standard improvement teams. Regarding the indicator of this outcome, to ensure the quality of UNDP's support to MARD, the MidTerm Review consultants suggest to change the indicator as "# of Manual on mainstreaming climate change into the design of rural infrastructure projects". Presently, consultant teams are working together to develop the manuals which are very coherent with each other (vulnerability index and Costs/Benefits calculation for instance). The methodologies to develop these manuals have been discussed with CPMU and UNDP based on the orientations/ expectations of the participants in the policy consultation workshop dated 29th May 2015. The expectations are mainly (i) a policy roadmap for MARD to adapt to climate change including possible technical standards; (ii) climate hazard risk maps and provincial planning based on these maps; (iii) low-cost and bio-engineering measures and (iv) related trainings. It is expected that first drafts of the manuals can be available in Quarter III/2015.

description.narrative: # of water resources standards and codes are informed to meet the requirements for climate resilience.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been any revision of water resources standards or codes.
By the end of the project at least 01 set of water resources standards informed by the project guidance.

On track with good progress. After a lot of consultations with both central and provincial levels showed that they all are very interested in upgrading codes/ standards or build a new set of standards to enable the application of new technologies or low-cost measures. Lack of these standards results in very time-consuming procedures in approval of bio-engineering interventions because MARD has no legal base for reference. This is also why demonstration subprojects managed by ADB have encountered a lot of difficulties regarding lack of related standards for their designs. Beside contributing to upgrading existing standards as mentioned in Indicator 2 of this Outcome, the project is (i) providing detailed recommendations on a key technical standard of Vietnam in irrigation named C6-77 regarding calculation of meteorological features of irrigation structures and (ii) developing rural infrastructure engineering manuals which will provide s technical guidance for MARD to develop their own low-cost solution guidelines and then standards in near future. Consultations were held with the technical staff of the Department of Science, Technology and Environment (MARD) and Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology, Environment and Climate Change (MONRE) on updating C6-77. MARD is considering updating this standard in coming years, and the project will provide some initial support to MARD regarding this standard as their expectations. In 2015, the project expects to deliver specific recommendations by QIII and then consult again with MARD and related agencies regarding these recommendations. UNDP has also been working closely with the ADB component to help create a link between target sites and Government policy development regarding low-cost measures. Based on the designs, site visits, experience and lessons learnt and together with other feasible lessons, the technical team will develop detailed technical guidance documents of low-cost measures.
N/A

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity to adapt/climate-proof rural infrastructure investments and provincial/local area planning.
Coverage of Climate risks and vulnerability assessment.

comment.narrative: There has not been any climate vulnerability assessment implemented for rural infrastructure in Northern mountain provinces.
A climate risks and vulnerability assessment for rural infrastructure done for all 15 northern provinces.

On track. As reported above, the assessment will cover 15 project provinces including Dien Bien, Lai Chau, Son la, Hoa Binh, Vinh Phuc, Phu Tho, Bac Giang, Bac Kan, Yen Bai, Lao Cai, Lang Son, Cao Bang, Thai Nguyen, Tuyen Quang and Ha Giang, then downscaled to Son La and Backan. After the vulnerability assessment methodology approved, the contractor sent their teams to all provinces and then all districts of two demonstration provinces as named above Son La and Backan to collect secondary data and interviews for missing data (O&M data). The types of structures under the assessment consist of (i) rural roads; (ii) river embankments; (iii) weirs; (iv) reservoirs and (v) main canals that are classified as categorical and continuous. The process tracks the following indicators: age of works, number of communes cut off from main road per year, past damages, number of secondary structures on road, material of road/ embankment, O&M, ratio of poor households, proportion of minorities, proportion of working age population, community contribution to infrastructure, number of site inspection, type of construction codes followed, number of times of damages, number of reservoirs stopped from functioning. Weightings are also laid for each kind of these indicators.Results show a picture of Son La, Backan and Ha Giang as the most vulnerable province in terms of risk. These results will be further deepened with specific recommendations provided by the project in the remaining time of the year. The next step will be to integrate these maps with future climate change projects.

description.narrative: # of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

comment.narrative: n/a – there has not been any rural infrastructure plan that is developed based on climate risk and vulnerability assessment.
At least two (02) provincial plans/strategy per target province (Son La and Bac Kan) guided as results of the project climate risks and vulnerability assessments, regarding mainstreaming of CC.

"Major planning decisions being modified due to vulnerability maps (in 2 target provinces)" indicator should be changed into "# of rural infrastructure investment plans guided as results of climate risks and vulnerability assessment, regarding mainstreaming of CC", which reflects better the influences of the project on the provinces because the project can only suggest the provinces to use the outputs. To date, climate risk and vulnerability maps have been provided to all target provinces for use in planning. Two PPCs (Backan and Sonla) have expressed their willingness to apply project recommendations into their investment plans. A provincial strategy expert who is being under recruitment of CPMU will take this work forward.
A team of provincial strategy development is under recruitment of CPMU. They will be mobilized in August as expected for review of existing provincial action plans and then recommend appropriate adjustments. If mapping packages can happen as expected, this team can take use of the maps for their recommendation report. Generally speaking, this activity is on track with a risk as indicated above.

description.narrative:
Level of capacity of provincial leaders to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning enhanced
% of technical personnel having ability to apply risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes

comment.narrative:
At the project outset, evaluated scores of management personnel in the 15 Northern provinces are as follows:
Institutional capacity on climate change adaptation (CCA) = 1.43/5
Organizational and planning capacity on CCA =1.71/5; and
Technical capacity on CCA = 1.78/5 Risk and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning is not yet available in Vietnam.

By the end of the project, capacity of provincial decision makers (DARD, DPI, DOT, DONRE) to climate-proof rural infrastructure investment and planning in the 15 northern mountainous provinces is at least (40%) higher than the project baseline; Up to 120 technical personnel from the 15 Northern provinces trained in CCA related issues and at least 50% of them having technical capability in applying climate risks and vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure development planning purposes.

On track with delay. This activity has started slower than the others because trainings had to be developed based on project results. Mobilized in Quarter II/2014, the capacity strengthening expert completed a capacity strengthening assessment focusing on institutional, organizational and technical capacities. These results reflect the baseline of the project. The assessment indicated a high level of demand for in improving the local capacity for climate change adaptation. In response to this, the project has decided to increase the number of training events by 40% Provincial stakeholders had a chance ot contribute to the design of the training programme through two consultation meetings. Trainings will focus on 04 topics namely (i) Policy for climate change resilience for senior provincial officials; (ii) Vulnerability assessment as a tool to increase climate change resilience for technical officers; (iii) Integrating climate change resilience into annual planning and prioritization and (iv) Training skills about climate change adaptation for provincial officials. As such, the details on vulnerability assessment tools and methods for rural infrastructure planning will bee transferred in (ii) and (iii). Target trainees include leaders and technical/ planning staff of 04 relevant provincial departments including Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Department of Transport, Department of Natural Resources and Environment and Department of Planning and Investment from 15 beneficiary provinces. Trainers will be project experts or outsourced from professional agencies such as Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Climate Change. There will be a total of 12 classes for 04 mentioned topics targeted to senior and technical level staff. Around 120 government personnel ware expected to be trained.

description.narrative: Effective climate-resilience measures mainstreamed into rural infrastructure programs.

The approaches developedâ€”including promising modifications, alternatives, and lessons learnedâ€”will be utilized by MARD rural infrastructure investments as standard practice in 100% of new ADB-financed projects by month 36.

comment.narrative: MARD has mainstreamed low cost climate measures for cross drainage structures by the use of drifts but not other measures.
1. Documentation identifying low cost climate proofing suitable for rural infrastructure in northern Viet Nam completed
There are no demonstrations of appropriate climate resilience techniques for rural infrastructure.
2. Demonstrations are successfully completed on four SRIDP subprojects by month 24.
3. Training carried out for 60 (â‰¥40% female) DARD staff from the 15 project provinces by month 34.
4. Recommendations completed and issued to the relevant institutions by month 34
5. Assessments for strengthening the climate resilience of the communities near the four subproject areas completed by month 30

description.narrative: Lessons learnt and best practices from Outcomes 1, 2 and 3 are disseminated to stakeholders and development partners
# of Project lessons and best practices captured, classified and evaluated;

comment.narrative: No project lessons learnt published by the project at the project outset

At least 08 articles/video clips/leaflets published by the end of the project
At least two (02) peer technical papers reviewed by the end of the project to facilitate professional discussion and advocacy

On track. Most of communication products will come at the final phase of the project to introduce project outputs. However, after the review phase, there were some articles published on websites/ magazines to (i) emphasize the necessity of climate adaptation in existing legal documents or (ii) draw attention to a number of technical adaptation measures. Articles published include: (1) “Integration of climate adaptation into relevant policy regarding water resources structures in Northern mountain region” published in Water Resources magazine in April 2015; (2) An article on the vulnerability assessment methodology workshop was published on 27th October 2014 by the Vietnam Science and Technology magazine (3) “Non-structural measures to protect slop at Northern Mountain region” by Mr. Hoang Tuan, Vice Director of Department of Construction Management (MARD) was published in on the VNCOLD website (Vietnam National Committee of Large Dams and Water Resources Development). Additional articles are under draft. The CPMU is recruiting a communication specialist who will help to capture project lessons, share experience through articles or videos.

description.narrative: Level of CCA knowledge and experiences documented and disseminated within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond

comment.narrative: 0 contributions.
At least 04 contributions by the end of the project (ALM records/ platforms)

Started. Project deliverables will be documented and shared within Vietnam, in the Asian region and beyond. It is expected that there will be low-cost measures documented to become manuals. Besides, future projects may also learn from both negative and positive lessons gained through a project management report. All of these products are under development and can be available in next year, 2016.

The project aims to enhance capacities of Committee for Flood and Storm Control at national, provincial and their partners in disaster risk management, specifically in humanitarian response and early recovery in context of climate changes.

title.narrative: Project Document of Disaster Risk Management (Phase II)
Mid- Term Evaluation for Strengthening Institutional Capacity for Disaster Risk Management in Viet Nam, including for Climate Change Related Risks Phase II

description.narrative: Disaster Risk Management 2-AUS
capital of a political entity
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1) Number of accompanying Decrees and legal documents developed and issued to support the promulgation of the Disaster Risk Management Law 2) Number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) policies, strategies and legislation revised to: - Embrace and keep track of changing dynamics of DRR, CCA and CC impacts; - Integrate gender equity and differing needs of vulnerable groups 3) Improvement of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - Number of direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The increasing of overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) Number of targeted vulnerable communes/wards have CBDRM plan of action developed under the CBDRM Programme 5) Number of “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1) Zero. By end of 2011, Version 3 of the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) Law was circulated to Ministries and for public consultation. A first draft of the accompanying Decree was produced 2) Zero. The existing overall disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) framework, though comprehensive, not yet reflecting the national, regional and international context and impacts of climate change, neither integrating gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups 3) Overall capacity scorecard of CCFSC was 2.2 points out of 5 points (2013) 4) None. 5) None. “Building blocks” are in the final stage of development, not yet rolled out.

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing;
2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR and CCA into SEDP - 01 guidelines and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong) 3) Improved technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - At least 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - Overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) No target for 2016 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; the CBDRM will be reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review completed on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing mechanism from 2016-2025; 2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised and approved by MPI/MARD, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR into SEDP approved by MPI in mid 2016 - 01 guidelines on mainstreaming gender in CDBRM, and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong)
3) Improved of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - More than 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The overall capacity scorecard points are not yet availalbe. (This will be updated as soon as the data are available.) 4) n/a 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; All the building blocks were shared to provinces via e-learning platform by Disaster Management Center under WRD/MARD; the national programme on CBDRM were reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval with extension until 2030.

description.narrative: 1) Number of accompanying Decrees and legal documents developed and issued to support the promulgation of the Disaster Risk Management Law 2) Number of disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) policies, strategies and legislation revised to: - Embrace and keep track of changing dynamics of DRR, CCA and CC impacts; - Integrate gender equity and differing needs of vulnerable groups 3) Improvement of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - Number of direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The increasing of overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) Number of targeted vulnerable communes/wards have CBDRM plan of action developed under the CBDRM Programme 5) Number of “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1) Zero. By end of 2011, Version 3 of the Disaster Risk Management (DRM) Law was circulated to Ministries and for public consultation. A first draft of the accompanying Decree was produced 2) Zero. The existing overall disaster risk reduction (DRR) and climate change adaptation (CCA) framework, though comprehensive, not yet reflecting the national, regional and international context and impacts of climate change, neither integrating gender equity and needs of vulnerable groups 3) Overall capacity scorecard of CCFSC was 2.2 points out of 5 points (2013) 4) None. 5) None. “Building blocks” are in the final stage of development, not yet rolled out.

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing;
2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR and CCA into SEDP - 01 guidelines and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong) 3) Improved technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - At least 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - Overall capacity scorecard points (to be indicated in the Capacity Assessment Report by end of 2016). 4) No target for 2016 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; the CBDRM will be reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval

1) No additional legal document; but 01 review completed on DRR financing, including for CBDRM financing mechanism from 2016-2025; 2) 03 DRR and CCA policies, strategies and legislation revised and approved by MPI/MARD, including: - 01 guideline on integrating DRR into SEDP approved by MPI in mid 2016 - 01 guidelines on mainstreaming gender in CDBRM, and 02 good practice reports on gender equity and promoting CBDRM guidelines for ethnic groups (Thai, Muong)
3) Improved of technical and functional capacity of Central Committee for Flood and Storm Control (CCFSC) and provincial stakeholders, measured by: - More than 1,000 direct beneficiaries of capacity building activities. - The overall capacity scorecard points are not yet availalbe. (This will be updated as soon as the data are available.) 4) n/a 5) 7/7 “building blocks” for the CBDRM programme approved and disseminated; All the building blocks were shared to provinces via e-learning platform by Disaster Management Center under WRD/MARD; the national programme on CBDRM were reviewed and revised for Gov’s approval with extension until 2030.

description.narrative: 1.1 Availability of a staff recruitment mechanism based on merit and competencies. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.2 Availability of a staff performance appraisal system (integrated into the staff management information system). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 1.3 Number of civil servants using the staff performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Availability of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: mechanism not available, 1: draft mechanism being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft mechanism finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: mechanism approved and implemented. 1.5 Availability of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: training programme not available, 1: draft training programme being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft training programme finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: training programme approved and implemented. 1.6 Availability of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: system not available, 1: draft system being prepared and shared for consultations, 2: draft system finalized and going through the formal approval process, 3: system approved and implemented. 2.1 Availability of a set of indicators and toolkits for assessment of satisfaction with the quality of public administrative services. Scaling from 0-3, where: 0: indicators and toolkits not available, 1: draft indicato

comment.narrative: 1.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a staff recruitment process based on merit and competencies. Current staff recruitment process is not based on competencies but mainly relies on diplomas, and certificates. 1.2 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a result-based staff performance appraisal system. A set of indicators and criteria to assess work performance of civil servants are being developed. 1.3 Zero civil servant use the staff performance appraisal system, which has not been made available at the beginning of the project. 1.4 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a mechanism for result-based remuneration for civil servants. Remuneration policies for civil servants are not based on merits but rather on performance-unrelated diplomas and seniority. 1.5 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a training programme specialized for different categories of civil servants. Civil servant structure is not available, without job description for each position. Education and training provided to civil servants is not based on job positions’ requirements. 1.6 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a modern staff management information system (including staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training, etc.). Current staff management information system needs to be upgraded towards online, and integrated with new modules such as staff recruitment, performance appraisal, training… 2.1 Rating: 0. Non-existence of a specialized and independent unit and standard tools for measuring the quality of public administrative services delivered to citizens and organizations. 2.2 Zero online feedbacks by citizens and organizations on quality of public administrative services delivery.

1.1 Rating: 2. The newly-developed recruitment guidelines officially applied in Da Nang city (using software application). 1.2 Rating: 3. The performance appraisal system finalized, submitted to relevant authorities (Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of the Government) and got approval of official application. 1.3 100% civil servants of Da Nang use the newly developed performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 No 2016 target for this indicator. 1.5 Rating: 3. 02 training curricula developed by Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) for different categories of civil servants reviewed, customized, taking into consideration of Da Nang context, and used officially in Da Nang city. 1.6 Rating: 3. The on-going comprehensive staff management information system is upgraded. 2.1 Rating: 3. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services upgraded. Legal framework and toolkit for customer satisfaction and PAR Index developed and applied. 2.2 68,000 online feedback on public administrative services provided on one-stop-shops performance. 7,000 direct feedback from other channels.

1.1 Rating: 2. The newly-developed recruitment guidelines officially applied in Da Nang city (using software application). 1.2 Rating: 3. The performance appraisal system finalized, submitted to relevant authorities (Ministry of Home Affairs, Office of the Government) and got approval of official application. 1.3 100% civil servants of Da Nang use the newly developed performance appraisal system on regular basis. 1.4 Not applicable, as there is no 2016 target for this indicator. 1.5 Rating: 3. 02 training curricula developed by Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) for different categories of civil servants reviewed, customized, taking into consideration of Da Nang context, and used officially in Da Nang city. 1.6 Rating: 3. The on-going comprehensive staff management information system is upgraded. 2.1 Rating: 3. 01 set of indicators for online assessment of users’ satisfactions on quality of public administrative services upgraded. Legal framework and toolkit for customer satisfaction and PAR Index developed and applied. 2.2 76,000 online feedback on public administrative services provided on one-stop-shops performance. 7,000 direct feedback from other channels.

title.narrative: Public Administration Reform project with MOHA

description.narrative: Support the implementation of Public Administration Reform (PAR) projects in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh provinces
Support the implementation of PAR projects in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh
Accountability - local government finance

1. Number of policy dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 Number of local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 Number of good practices piloted in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 Number of good practices, documents and publications (i.e movie) reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives. 2.4 Number of national regulations developed/revised, using inputs from 4 local projects.

comment.narrative: 1. Non-existence of regular dialogues between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues. 2.1 Local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh received limited technical support from the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA). 2.2 Non-existence of PAR good practices on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery in 4 localities Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh. 2.3 Local knowledge and experiences on PAR are not gathered, processed and documented for systematic, wide and continuous circulation. 2.4 Local initiatives on public human resource reform and public administration service delivery are not effectively used by MOHA for national regulations development/revision.

1. 05 policy dialogue between central and local levels and among localities on PAR issues organized. 2.1 10 local PAR initiatives in Bac Giang, Can Tho, Da Nang and Ha Tinh supported. 2.2 05 initiative piloted in one locality used/replicated by other localities. 2.3 08 good practices, reflecting lessons drawn from local PAR initiatives, documented. 2.4 03 proposals provided to MOHA for consideration in development of national regulations on PAR.

1. Number of approved guidelines for National REDD+ Action Plan implementation 2. Number of fund created and operated for mobilizing investment in REDD+ 3. Number of site REDD+ action plan 4. Number of people benefiting from Site activities 5. Number of policy/design options for benefit sharing from result-based payment 6. Number of Grievance mechanisms for REDD+ 7. Number of Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

comment.narrative:
At the beginning of 2013:
1. Number of approved guidelines for National REDD+ Action Plan implementation: 0 2. Number of fund created and operated for mobilizing investment in REDD+ : 0 3. Number of site REDD+ action plan: 0 4. Number of people benefiting from Site activities: 0 5. Number of policy/design options for benefit sharing from result-based payment:0 6. Number of Grievance mechanisms for REDD+:0 7. Number of Safeguards Information System created to monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards: 0

1) 01 National REDD+ Action Programme (NRAP) is revised in accordance with UNFCCC's related provisions and international good practices. 2) No target for 2016 3) 17 Site REDD+ plans are approved and implemented. 4) About 200,000 people (51% are female) benefit from site activities 5) Participatory Governance Assessment starts its replication into 4 provinces. 6) 02 PRAPs - Provincial REDD+ Action Plans of Lao Cai and Binh Thuan are formulated and put under implementation 7) 1 safeguards Information System created monitor impacts of - REDD+ interventions on Safeguards

1) The revised NRAP is submitted to Gov. office for final approval fo PM in December 2016. This is rated "good" quality by the independent review of the Programme for 2016. 2) Not applicable, as no target was set for 2016 3) 17 Site REDD+ Plans approved and agreements on funding have been signed off. Implementation started from quarter III and will last for 2 years. 4) About 331,000 people (51% are women) are benefiting from site activities from 2016 until 2018 5) PGA are under replication in 4 provinces including Lam Dong, Lao Cai, Ca Mau and Ha Tinh and led by Forest Protection Department (VNFOREST) 6) 02 PRAPs of Lao Cai and Binh Thuan have been approved in April 2016 and under implementation 7) SIS framework finalized by December 2016

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: 1) Number of strategic leaders trained with the revised gender-sensitive curriculum at the Ho Chi Minh Political Academy (HCMA). 2) Number of female officials participated in Women’s Leadership Program that was developed and institutionalized in HCMA. 3) Representation of women in Party Committees, National Assembly and People’s Councils 4) Number of female officers in the public sector having access to training courses on soft skills and participate in a mentoring programme. 5) Availability of the human resource procedures that promote women’s participation in leadership positions 6) Number of female officers who have access to the research grant program 7) Number of draft laws that have gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members 8) The extent to which university curriculum is gender sensitive (Scale: 0-not at all; 1-very litte; 2-little; 3-significant; 4-very significant)

comment.narrative: 1) 0. Existing training programs at the HCMA, its sub academies, and 63 provincial political schools are gender blind. 2) 0. Women in the public sector have limited access to professional leadership training programs run by government institutions. Few women civil servants receive training in leadership or management skills 3) For the 2011-2016 term, the percentage of women is 9% for the Central Committee of the Communist Party, 24.4% for the National Assembly, and less than 28% for the People’s Councils at all levels. 4) Women in the public sector have limited access to professional leadership training programs run by government institutions. 5) No availability. The current hiring, promotion and selection for training process in the civil service have not met the targets of the Strategy on Gender Equality. 6) 43 female officers were awarded research grants since 2009. However, the quality of their research and their understanding of gender mainstreaming still varies. 7) 0 law 8) 0-not at all. Most of university curriculum used in Viet Nam are gender blind.

1) 200 strategic leaders trained with this revised gender-sensitive curriculum. 2) 35 trainers benefited from the TOT training. 3) Women representation is higher than the current proportions (24.4% in NA and 25.7% in provincial people’s councils) 4) At least 30 female officers in the public sector participated in UNDP-supported training on leadership skills and mentoring programmes. 5) No target for 2016 6) No target for 2016 7) At least 1 draft law that has gender analysis conducted and fed to national law drafting team and National Assembly members 8) No target for 2016

1) Cumulative direct CO2 emission reductions resulting from the NFB plant investments and technical assistance (Mtons CO2) 2) Cumulative direct energy saving (TOE) from displacement of coal through the demonstration NFB plants 3) Number of approved and enforced policies to encourage increased production and use of NFBs and decreased use of fired clay bricks (FCBs) 4) Number of approved and enforced policies and standards for the local manufacture of NFB equipment and technology 5) Number of trained government officers in NFB quality control standards and regulations and new building codes mandating the use of NFBs 6) Number of new NFB plants that were designed and constructed by local engineering firms based on new NFB technical guidelines 7) Number of financing institutions providing financial products for NFB investments 8) Number of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and NFB entrepreneurs with confirmed financing through Project financial schemes 9) Number of NFB demonstration plants in operation with a 90% capacity factor 10) % of market share of NFBs in the local brick market

1) Cumulative direct CO2 emission reductions resulting from the NFB plant investments and technical assistance (Mtons CO2) 2) Cumulative direct energy saving (TOE) from displacement of coal through the demonstration NFB plants 3) Number of approved and enforced policies to encourage increased production and use of NFBs and decreased use of fired clay bricks (FCBs) 4) Number of approved and enforced policies and standards for the local manufacture of NFB equipment and technology 5) Number of trained government officers in NFB quality control standards and regulations and new building codes mandating the use of NFBs 6) Number of new NFB plants that were designed and constructed by local engineering firms based on new NFB technical guidelines 7) Number of financing institutions providing financial products for NFB investments 8) Number of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and NFB entrepreneurs with confirmed financing through Project financial schemes 9) Number of NFB demonstration plants in operation with a 90% capacity factor 10) % of market share of NFBs in the local brick market

description.narrative: 1. M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy and Action Plan 2. Guideline on green growth investment. 3. Guideline for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plan. 4. Number of sectoral and provincial GG action plans with GHG emission targets. 5. Communication action plan, and number of events and media coverage. 6. Number of policy studies and dialogues relating to green investments, green transportation, green procurement and financial tools for green development. 7. Level of availability of financial data and information to interested stakeholders. 8. Number of report on climate public and private expenditures. 9. Number of green growth projects ideas and proposals.

comment.narrative: 1. M& E mechanism is not in place. 2. No guideline is in place. 3. No guideline is in place. 4. No GG action plan has been formulated for target sectors and provinces. 5. Communication action plan is not in place. 6. Limited studies have been produced by other development partners. 7. A UNDP-WB supported website in place and some scattered information in various websites. 8. No report on climate finance expenditures produced; 9. No green growth projects ideas and proposals by businesses in place

1) The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy finalized 2) Guideline on green growth investment drafted 3) A national guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans completed 4) At least one provincial Green Growth action plan with GHG emission reduction targets formulated. 5) Communication strategy formulated 6) Seven studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development conducted. 7) Some financial data and information on public expenditure are available 8) Scoping report on climate private expenditures prepared. 9) No target for 2016

1) The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy finalized 2) Guideline on green growth investment drafted 3) A national guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans completed and awaiting for approval by MPI 4) 2 action plans: Da Lat Green Growth Action Plan approved and Ha Nam Green Growth Action Plan finalized and pending for a formal approval 5) Communication strategy finalized and several events organized 6) Seven studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development conducted 7) Some financial data and information on public expenditure are available and published 8) Scoping report on climate private expenditures finalized and final report drafted 9) Not applicable, as no target was set for 2016

comment.narrative: 1. M& E mechanism is not in place. 2. No guideline is in place. 3. No guideline is in place. 4. No GG action plan has been formulated for target sectors and provinces. 5. Communication action plan is not in place. 6. Limited studies have been produced by other development partners. 7. A UNDP-WB supported website in place and some scattered information in various websites. 8. No report on climate finance expenditures produced; 9. No green growth projects ideas and proposals by businesses in place

1) The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy finalized 2) Guideline on green growth investment drafted 3) A national guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans completed 4) At least one provincial Green Growth action plan with GHG emission reduction targets formulated. 5) Communication strategy formulated 6) Seven studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development conducted. 7) Some financial data and information on public expenditure are available 8) Scoping report on climate private expenditures prepared. 9) No target for 2016

1) The M& E mechanism for Viet Nam Green Growth Strategy finalized 2) Guideline on green growth investment drafted 3) A national guidelines for preparation of sectoral and provincial green growth action plans completed and awaiting for approval by MPI 4) 2 action plans: Da Lat Green Growth Action Plan approved and Ha Nam Green Growth Action Plan finalized and pending for a formal approval 5) Communication strategy finalized and several events organized 6) Seven studies on green transportation and financial tools for green development conducted 7) Some financial data and information on public expenditure are available and published 8) Scoping report on climate private expenditures finalized and final report drafted 9) Not applicable, as no target was set for 2016
